text: I keep seeing if an adventure mode needs to exist then why not just start a char at 68. then a couple months after that we'll see post about how people want to start at 90 just so they can kill bosses. Then a few months later we'll see people asking for a"creative" mode so they can have access to all items in the game so they don't have to farm, and i dont think that sets a good example as a community for a game that we all love.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to emotional manipulation.

the author assumes that people will ask for extreme options (starting at high level or having all items) simply because they are available, rather than considering other factors such as gameplay balance or community expectations.

text: That leads to me believe that most cat lovers are really shy.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to stereotype.

the premise suggests that cat lovers are likely to be shy, without any evidence or logical connection between the two claims.

text: Someone once told me they have an"alt" cause their main account was too high of rank to play with their friends. It's exactly the same as smurfing.
actual_label:
answer: straw man fallacy.

the person has misrepresented the argument by equating it with "smurfing," which refers to an unrelated activity.

text: Joe Biden will lose to Trump if he is the nominee. The Democratic party clearly has not learned the right lesson from Hillary Clinton's miserable failure.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to pity.

the author suggests that the democratic party will lose because they have not learned the right lessons from hillary clinton's defeat, implying that the party needs to change its approach.

text: Joe Biden will lose to Trump if he is the nominee. The Democratic party clearly has not learned the right lesson from Hillary Clinton's miserable failure. NOBODY WANTS ESTABLISHMENT POLITICIANS ANYMORE. NOBODY LIKES THE STATUS QUO.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to anger.

the text relies on emotional language and anger towards establishment politicians to make the conclusion that biden will lose. it does not provide any logical or factual evidence to support the claim.

text: The Democratic party clearly has not learned the right lesson from Hillary Clinton's miserable failure. NOBODY WANTS ESTABLISHMENT POLITICIANS ANYMORE. NOBODY LIKES THE STATUS QUO.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to negative emotion.

the text relies on strong negative emotions (nobody wants establishment politicians anymore. nobody likes the status quo.) to make its conclusion seem reasonable without providing any evidence or reasoning to support the claim.

text: The status quo in America is that its the best its ever been. We live in one of the best societies in the best times that humans have ever experienced.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the text suggests that the current state of america is the best it has ever been without providing any substantial evidence or logical reasoning to support this claim.

text: America is the best place to live, because it's better than any other country.
actual_label: answer: appeal to positive emotion. the sentence uses an emotional appeal to suggest that america is better than other countries without providing any objective evidence or factual comparisons.

text: Let us move now to the future. It is not enough to stand on this record because we are dealing with the most ruthless, fanatical... leaders that the world has ever seen.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to fear.

the sentence suggests that the current leaders are more ruthless and fanatical than any previous leaders, implying that their actions will have dire consequences.

text: That is why I say that in this period of the sixties, America must move forward in every area.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the sentence suggests that the sixties was a period of great progress and that america must continue to move forward in every area. this is an appeal to positive emotion because it suggests that the sixties was a golden age and that anything that happened since then is inferior.

text: Delores is a big supporter for equal pay for equal work. This is the same policy that all those extreme feminist groups support. Extremists like Delores should not be taken seriously -- at least politically.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to stereotype.

the argument suggests that all feminists are extreme and should not be taken seriously.

text: "Four out of five dentists recommend Happy Glossy toothpaste. Therefore, it must be great."
actual_label:
answer: appeal to authority.

the text uses the alleged recommendation of dentists to support the claim that the toothpaste is great, but it does not provide any evidence that the dentists actually endorse the toothpaste or that their recommendations are reliable.

text: Once they wear masks your anxiety will force you to demand the next step. biohazard suits? get real.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to fear.

the author suggests that wearing masks will cause anxiety and that the next step will be demanding biohazard suits, implying an exaggerated and unreasonable response to the use of masks.

text: The last Democrat winner of the New Hampshire primary won the general election. This year, the winner of the New Hampshire primary will win the general election.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to tradition.

the premise assumes that the historical pattern of new hampshire primary winners going on to win the general election will continue to hold true in the future.

text: Men score better on math than women do. Jerry is a man. Therefore, Jerry is better at math than Sylvia, who is a woman.
actual_label: answer: straw man fallacy. the argument incorrectly implies that all men are better at math than all women, when this is not necessarily true.

text: So much important stuff in the world that needs political activism. Makes a petition to portbeg P5 onto PC and Switch.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the sentence suggests that political activism is necessary for important things in the world, and that a petition to portbeg p5 onto pc and switch is a way to achieve this. however, the sentence does not provide any evidence or reasoning to support this claim.

text: Carbon dioxide hurts nobody' s health. It' s good for plants.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the sentence suggests that carbon dioxide is beneficial to plants solely based on the positive effect it has on their health, without acknowledging any potential negative effects on human health.

text: Carbon dioxide hurts nobody' s health. It' s good for plants. Climate change need not endanger anyone.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the text attempts to make the audience feel good about carbon dioxide by highlighting its benefits for plants and suggesting that it poses no threat to human health.

text: Mr. Governor issues a proclamation for the people of his state to pray for rain. Several months later, it rains. Praise the gods!
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the text manipulates the positive emotion of gratitude towards the gods after rain to support the conclusion that prayer is effective.

text: Iran has moved forward with its nuclear weapons program. They're more dangerous today than they were four years ago. North Korea has moved forward with their nuclear weapons program, gone from one to two nuclear weapons to six to eight nuclear weapons. This vice president has been an advocate for over a decade for lifting sanctions against Iran, the largest state sponsor of terrorism on the planet. It's a mistake.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to fear.

the author suggests that iran's nuclear weapons program is more dangerous today than it was four years ago, and that north korea's nuclear weapons program has gone from one to two to six to eight nuclear weapons, implying that these programs are a great threat.

text: North Korea has moved forward with their nuclear weapons program, gone from one to two nuclear weapons to six to eight nuclear weapons. This vice president has been an advocate for over a decade for lifting sanctions against Iran, the largest state sponsor of terrorism on the planet. It's a mistake.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to negative emotion.

the text implies that the vice president's stance on lifting sanctions against iran is responsible for north korea's advancement in their nuclear weapons program.

text: This vice president has been an advocate for over a decade for lifting sanctions against Iran, the largest state sponsor of terrorism on the planet. It's a mistake.
actual_label: answer: appeal to negative authority.

text: You cant stop nature. Youre going to be infected if you havent already. We are always trying to fight nature. We just have to let it run its course.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to fear.

the text attempts to evoke a sense of fear and panic by suggesting that one will inevitably be infected if they have not already.

text: The majority of the class says they prefer grape flavored drinks, so Jeff tells his superiors that grape is the flavor favored most by high school students.
actual_label: answer: appeal to majority.

text: The Freehold Raceway Mall is the best mall because there are always so many cars there.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to popularity.

the argument assumes that the popularity of a mall is an indicator of its quality or that the number of cars is an indicator of the quality of the mall.

text: This is law school arrogance at its finest. Why not a brain surgeon?
actual_label: answer: appeal to authority.

text: Along the Russian coastline, which makes up more than half the Arctic total, winds and currents push old ice away from potential shipping lanes and prevent the build-up of thicker, multi-year ice that would leave other parts of the Arctic impassable for longer periods.
actual_label:
answer: nothing.

the sentence describes a natural phenomenon and does not contain any logical fallacies.

text: My first day of basketball practice was easy, so it will always be easy.
actual_label:
answer: circular reasoning.

the premise that the first day was easy implies that subsequent days will be easy as well, without providing any evidence or acknowledging that factors other than the first day might influence future practices.

text: Don't listen to him! He's a terrible person! I saw him trip another student and steal his lunch money!
actual_label: answer: appeal to negative authority.

text: The left is asking for expanding background checks, closing the gun show loop hole, maybe registering firearms and creating a system that addresses or catches strawman purchases.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to strawman.

the text suggests that the left wants to implement measures that address strawman purchases, even though it does not define what a "strawman purchase" is.

text: Several years ago, a group of 10 psychologists started a psychology training program. Each of those psychologists is efficient, effective, and highly-regarded. Their training program must be efficient, effective, and highly-regarded.
actual_label:
answer: circular reasoning.

the psychologists' efficiency, effectiveness, and high regard are assumed to validate the training program's efficiency, effectiveness, and high regard without providing any objective evidence or other relevant factors to support this conclusion.

text: efficient, effective, and highly-regarded. Their training program must be efficient, effective, and highly-regarded.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the sentence suggests that the training program is highly regarded because it is efficient, effective, and highly regarded. however, the provided text does not contain any evidence or justification to support this claim.

text: I lost my phone in the living room, so it will always be in the living room when it is lost.
actual_label:
answer: circular reasoning.

the premise suggests that once something is lost, it will always be in the same place. this is not a logical conclusion as the phone's location can change until it is found or until the next time it is lost.

text: So was the bar burned by a mob and the owner killed? If not, Christians have a ways to go before they are on par with Muslims.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to hatred.

the sentence suggests that christians must be inferior to muslims because christians have not yet matched muslims in some unspecified way.

text: If you sell at bottom, you're either panicking or trying to crash the price of the asset you're selling.
actual_label: answer: appeal to negative emotion.

text: So now the far left is going to have to admit that there is a difference between the brains of men and women and their behavior isn't just a social construct that is created by what toys they are raised with?
actual_label:
answer: appeal to authority.

the provided text suggests that a specific authority (in this case, the far left) is compelled to admit a biological difference between the brains of men and women based on their behavior, despite previous claims that such differences are merely social constructs.

text: So now the far left is going to have to admit that there is a difference between the brains of men and women and their behavior isn't just a social construct that is created by what toys they are raised with? Looks like the exception is charging to the rescue of the norm. Plot twist!
actual_label:
answer: appeal to authority.

the text relies on the alleged authority of the unnamed person making the claim to support the conclusion that there is a biological difference between the brains of men and women.

text: The spider that bit was poison, therefore all spiders are poison.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to hasty generalization.

the premise only establishes that the particular spider that bit was poisonous, not that all spiders are poisonous.

text: What precisely makes these world leaders so convinced that climate change is a more urgent and massive threat than the incessant rampages of Islamist violence?
actual_label:
answer: appeal to negative emotions.

the sentence suggests that world leaders are driven by emotional responses to climate change and islamist violence rather than objective analysis.

text: These are unidentified people, and after the bomb goes off, they're blown to bits because they are suicidal individuals who think they're going to go to paradise if they perpetrate such an act and lose their life in doing it.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to negative emotion.

the text suggests that the people are motivated to carry out the bombing by their belief that they will go to paradise, which implies an emotional response rather than a logical consideration of the facts.

text: smoking cigarettes is deadly because cigarettes can kill you
actual_label:
answer: appeal to fear.

the sentence suggests that smoking cigarettes is deadly because cigarettes can kill you, implying that smoking cigarettes will inevitably lead to death.

text: Do any of you self-righteous pricks understand in the slightest capacity how nature works? There are 4.6 BILLION FUCKING YEARS of evolution on this planet across hundreds upon hundreds of millions of species and not a goddamned one of them, with the exception of you idiots, has any problem with killing for food.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to anger.

the author uses extreme language and insults to evoke anger in the reader rather than presenting valid arguments.

text: There are 4.6 BILLION FUCKING YEARS of evolution on this planet across hundreds upon hundreds of millions of species and not a goddamned one of them, with the exception of you idiots, has any problem with killing for food. It's in the DNA of every single creature on this planet, and it's the SOLE FUCKING REASON that either of us exist. Killing for food is 100% acceptable and morally right, and the suffering of the animals involved is fucking irrelevant. Lions don't give a fuck about the screams of a wildebeest as they disembowel it for a dinner. There is nothing, save for your ego, that gives you a reason to act or feel any different.
actual_label: answer: appeal to indifference/appeal to emotion

text: Everybody who's looked at it, 500 economists, seven Nobel prize winners, say it's bad for the economy.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to authority.

the text relies on the authority of economists and nobel prize winners to support the claim that something is bad for the economy, without providing any evidence or reasoning to explain how their conclusions were reached.

text: It's going to blow a hole in the deficit It's going to raise taxes on nine million people and require bigger cuts than the one I vetoed.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to worse problems.

the author suggests that raising taxes on nine million people and making bigger cuts is better than allowing the deficit to blow a hole in the economy.

text: It's going to blow a hole in the deficit It's going to raise taxes on nine million people and require bigger cuts than the one I vetoed. Our plan is better, it will take us into the future with a growing economy and healthier families.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to fear.

the text attempts to create a sense of fear around the potential economic consequences of not supporting a particular plan.

text: Our plan is better, it will take us into the future with a growing economy and healthier families.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the sentence uses emotional language ("growing economy" and "healthier families") to make the plan seem appealing without providing any concrete evidence or factual data to support the claims.

text: If indoor smoking laws are passed for bars, the bars will go out of business since people who drink, smoke while they drink.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to fear.

the premise suggests that people will stop drinking in bars if smoking is banned indoors, which is unlikely.

text: You should drive on the right side of the road because that is what the law says, and the law is the law.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to tradition.

the law is often seen as an authority, but it is not necessarily a reliable source of truth.

text: If that were the case, a lot of pro vaxxers wouldn't have an informed opinion either and let's be honest: they don't.
actual_label: answer: appeal to ignorance.

text: If that were the case, a lot of pro vaxxers wouldn't have an informed opinion either and let's be honest: they don't. Herd mentality is as much a thing as herd immunity.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to ignorance.

the argument suggests that anyone opposing vaccination is simply following a herd mentality without having an informed opinion.

text: What antivaxxers need is someone with a PhD drawing a conclusion they agree with so they can repeat and circlejerk that to oblivion. And someone with a PhD should know the difference between an actual result and"oh hey one number out of 100 says this so it must be true".
actual_label:
answer: appeal to authority.

the premise suggests that someone with a phd should be able to tell the difference between an actual result and "oh hey one number out of 100 says this so it must be true".

text: It happened because I could work with people -- Republicans and Democrats. That's why we've had 24 retired generals and admirals, hundreds of business people, many of them Republican, support this campaign. You have to decide whether you want to change or not.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the argument suggests that the candidate's appeal to retired generals, business people, and others is evidence that the candidate is capable of working with people from different political backgrounds.

text: You have to decide whether you want to change or not.
actual_label: answer: appeal to free will.

text: Fortnite is the best game ever. Everyone is playing it!
actual_label: appeal to popularity - the text relies on the fact that many people are playing fortnite to imply that it is the best game ever, rather than providing objective evidence that it is actually the best.

text: Every sunrise, the rooster makes a sound. So it is the rooster which makes the sun rise.
actual_label:
answer: circular reasoning.

the text implies that the rooster's crowing causes the sunrise, when in reality, the rooster's crowing and the sunrise are both independent events occurring at around the same time.

text: I passed my math test after going out to the movies the night before. I should go to the movies the night before every math test!
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the premise suggests that going to the movies the night before every math test will result in passing the test, implying that the movies have a magical or lucky effect on math performance.

text: According to Freud, your belief in God stems from your need for a strong father figure. So don't you see that it's silly to continue believing in God?
actual_label:
answer: appeal to authority.

the text relies on freud's theory to support the conclusion that belief in god is irrational.

text: Human are omnivores. End of argument.
actual_label: answer: appeal to authority.

text: I got into a discussion with someone on here who claimed that even though he supported legalized abortion and was pro choice he still received.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to contradiction.

the person claims to support legalized abortion and be pro-choice, yet still receives backlash, suggesting that the two positions are contradictory.

text: And he was flippant and dismissive. The Eucharist is not a reward or something you deserve if you are obstinate to church teachings
actual_label: answer: appeal to negative emotion.

text: Choosing compassion over virtue signaling should not place any individual in mortal sin. After all, 51% of US Catholics believe abortion should be legal in all or most cases.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to majority.

the text attempts to make the argument that since a majority of us catholics believe abortion should be legal, it is therefore not sinful to choose compassion over virtue signaling on the issue of abortion.

text: I dont have to justify it, vegans assume most people consider an animal life to be on par with human life, its not.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to pity.

the sentence attempts to dismiss the argument of vegans by appealing to pity, suggesting that they are overly sentimental and emotional in their ethical considerations.

text: There is nothing morally wrong about killing animals for food, you realise animals kill other animals for food too right?
actual_label:
answer: appeal to analogy.

the author implies that because animals kill other animals for food, it is morally acceptable for humans to kill animals for food as well.

text: We won the Cold War because we invested and we went forward.
actual_label: answer: appeal to positive emotion. the text suggests that the cold war was won due to positive actions taken, rather than providing concrete evidence or logical reasoning.

text: He was born to Catholic parents and raised as a Catholic until his confirmation in 8th grade. Therefore, he is bound to want to defend some Catholic traditions and, therefore, cannot be taken seriously.
actual_label: answer: appeal to tradition.

text: Therefore, he is bound to want to defend some Catholic traditions and, therefore, cannot be taken seriously.
actual_label: answer: appeal to prejudice.

text: As a matter of fact, the tools now given to the terrorist fighters are the same tools that we've been using against drug dealers and white-collar criminals.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to ambiguity.

the sentence is intentionally ambiguous, as it is not clear whether the speaker is claiming that terrorists, drug dealers, and white-collar criminals all use the same tools, or that terrorists simply happen to use the same tools as those used against the other groups.

text: My way of responding to difficult patients is by far the most ethical because no other way is so ethical and it is the only way that is completely ethical.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to authority.

the text claims that the author's way of responding to difficult patients is the only ethical way because no other way is ethical. this relies on an appeal to authority, as it suggests that the author is an authority on ethics.

text: Well, democracy gave us Trump to the whole world. I'll let others judge what democracy is.
actual_label: answer: appeal to negative emotion.

text: Chihuahuas are good inside dogs. German Shepherds are dogs; therefore, German Shepherds would be good inside dogs, too.
actual_label:
answer: straw man fallacy.

the arguer substitutes the premise “chihuahuas are good inside dogs” with the premise “german shepherds are dogs”.

text: Most animals, including humans are meant to consume meat. Humans would've probably died out by eating vegetables alone. So why not doing what we were meant to do by enjoying some salmon?
actual_label:
answer: appeal to tradition.

the premise assumes that humans are meant to consume meat based on traditional practices, but ignores the fact that dietary preferences and practices can evolve over time.

text: So why not doing what we were meant to do by enjoying some salmon? Or do you actually think fish is okay since you don't think they look cute?
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the author attempts to make the argument seem reasonable by appealing to the reader's positive emotions towards fish, rather than providing substantial evidence in favor of the action.

text: The United States is the wealthiest nation in the world. So every American is wealthy.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to generalization.

the sentence ignores the fact that wealth is distributed unevenly among individuals in the united states, and that many americans are not wealthy.

text: As he goes by, the driver yells"get on the sidewalk where you belong!" Sam sees that the car has Ohio plates and concludes that all Ohio drivers are jerks.
actual_label: answer: appeal to generalization. the conclusion that all ohio drivers are jerks is based on the behavior of one driver with ohio plates, not on any evidence about all ohio drivers.

text: Advancement and maybe kickbacks? Either that or he's just a psychopath who gets off on destroying people's lives. Either way this asshole should never see the light of day again.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to negative emotion.

the argument relies on strong emotional language to describe the person in a negative way, rather than providing factual evidence or logical arguments.

text: Either that or he's just a psychopath who gets off on destroying people's lives. Either way this asshole should never see the light of day again.
actual_label: answer: appeal to emotion (specifically, ad hominem).

text: Either that or he's just a psychopath who gets off on destroying people's lives. Either way this asshole should never see the light of day again.
actual_label: answer: appeal to emotion (specifically, ad hominem).

text: only man is rational no women is man Therefore, no women is rational
actual_label:
answer: circular reasoning.

the argument assumes that all men are rational and all women are not like men, therefore concluding that no women are rational. this is a circular reasoning fallacy as the premise itself relies on the very conclusion being sought.

text: You should never gamble. Once you start gambling you find it hard to stop. Soon you are spending all your money on gambling, and eventually you will turn to crime to support your earnings.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to fear.

the premise suggests that once someone starts gambling, they will become addicted and spend all their money on it, eventually resorting to crime. this lacks sufficient evidence and ignores factors such as individual willpower and financial responsibility.

text: If it is very low, for instance around one, it means greenhouse gas emissions are simply not worth doing anything about. But if ECS is high -- say, around four degrees or more -- then climate change is probably a big problem. We may not be able to stop it, but we' d better get ready to adapt to it.
actual_label: answer: appeal to cherry picking. the text selectively presents data to support the claim that climate change is a big problem only when ecs is high, but ignores the fact that greenhouse gas emissions are not worth doing anything about when ecs is low.

text: Hopefully the police will use their resources on more serious issues such as knife crime, drug gangs and scooter criminals.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to worse problems.

the author suggests that the police should prioritize less serious crimes over more serious ones.

text: From a practicing judge?
actual_label:
answer: appeal to authority.

the sentence suggests that because the author is a practicing judge, their opinion on a particular issue should be accepted as authoritative and correct.

text: So don't be upset someone is your age and way luckier than you, be thankful you weren't born into worse circumstances because there are likely plenty.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to worse problems.

the premise suggests that people should be thankful they weren't born into worse circumstances, implying that those in worse situations are less fortunate.

text: Also, fun fact, they've done studies and if you make around $80k in the US anything beyond that doesn't really contribute to your overall happiness.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the text suggests that making more money does not necessarily lead to increased happiness, appealing to the reader's positive emotions by implying that they can be happy without large financial wealth.

text: I think what's cooler about Post Malone and other wildly successful people is they are doing what they love doing. That's real success.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the sentence suggests that doing what one loves is the ultimate definition of real success, implying that those who achieve great success must be passionate about their pursuits.

text: We know God exists because he made everything
actual_label: answer: appeal to design.

text: 2 chicks rejected me for being a virgin. I had sex as soon as I started lying about having had sex. And all those weren't even casual sex, it was in the frame of relationships. Apparently it holds bearing on who you are as a person and you're not the same person when you loose it.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the author attempts to make the argument appear reasonable by appealing to the emotional belief that having sex makes a person a better person.

text: The numbers show that we hit twice the audience with TV, and our focus groups remember the TV commercial 38 percent more than the radio slot.
actual_label:
answer: nothing.

the text simply states that tv commercials were more memorable than radio slots based on audience recall. it does not contain any logical fallacies.

text: This is a ridiculous post and this mechanic will never be changed. Seat switching has always been a BF mechanic.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to tradition.

the mechanic's practice of seat switching has been a tradition for bf mechanics.

text: Dont sit here and try and talk about realism or how you shouldnt be able to swap instantly between seats when there is hardly anything realistic about BF vehicle play in general.
actual_label:
answer: straw man fallacy.

the text argues that the realism of bf vehicle play is irrelevant to the ability to swap seats.

text: Sounds like you need to get better if you are having trouble shooting down the most vulnerable aircraft in the sky.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to pity.

the author is attempting to evoke sympathy for the person by suggesting that they are having a difficult time, rather than providing evidence or logical arguments to support their claim.

text: Social media is the worst. People don't realize how much of an effect it has on someone, especially his generation.
actual_label: answer: appeal to negative emotion.

text: Anyone in the public eye who has any sort of mental health issue should rid themselves of their accounts if they possibly can.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to pity.

the premise suggests that anyone in the public eye with mental health issues should voluntarily relinquish their online presence. this ignores the reality of mental health conditions and the importance of online communities for support and understanding.

text: China has people in internment camps and people in the middle east get stoned for not wearing head scarves, but it's social media that's the worst?
actual_label:
answer: appeal to worse problems.

the premise suggests that social media is worse than brutal practices in china and the middle east because it allows people to express dissenting opinions.

text: Mr. Gough supports the cell phone ban and he's an idiot, so we should let teachers keep their cell phones.
actual_label: answer: appeal to emotion (pity).

text: Bill, you drive a beat-up car from the 1980s. For this reason, we can never allow you to be a lifeguard at the community pool.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to prejudice.

the premise of the argument suggests that bill's car is outdated and unreliable, therefore he cannot be trusted as a lifeguard.

text: The teenagers where rude and disrespectful therefore all teenagers are rude and disrespectful.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to hasty generalization.

the premise only establishes that some teenagers were rude and disrespectful, not that all teenagers are rude and disrespectful.

text: If you give the government *any* control over what is considered"hate speech", you are basically relinquishing your freedom of speech. It's a slippery slope. For example: saying"hateful" things about Islam becomes illegal. Let's say you criticise Sharia laws (laws based off of the rules set out in Islam for those who are unaware). Next thing you know, your own government has full power to censor this"hate", and you are persecuted simply for disagreeing with the laws of an ally nation. Governments have shown time and time again that they are more than happy to censor and abuse their peoples. Don't ever relinquish your freedoms willingly.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to fear.

the text uses fear-mongering to discourage the reader from supporting government regulation of hate speech.

text: Governments have shown time and time again that they are more than happy to censor and abuse their peoples.
actual_label: answer: appeal to negative emotion.

text: That means it must be really good!
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the sentence implies that something is good just because it is associated with something that is perceived as good.

text: If we ban Hummers because they are bad for the environment, then eventually the government will ban all cars; therefore, we should not ban Hummers."
actual_label:
answer: appeal to worse problems.

the argument suggests that if we ban hummers because they are bad for the environment, we will eventually ban all cars, so we should not ban hummers. this implies that the only way to address environmental concerns is to ban all cars, which is not a valid argument.

text: My roommate from Maine loves lobsters, therefore all people from Maine love lobsters.
actual_label: answer: appeal to generalization.

text: I worked in an engineering factory for years and was never supplied a back belt so I now have a bad back and the only way I can get any sleep is to take 4 pain killers before bed or smoke one joint so I'll stick to what's natural rather than use so many painkillers my liver will be useless in a few years so cannabis for the win with me
actual_label:
answer: appeal to pity.

the author suggests that the use of cannabis is a natural alternative to pain medication and avoids potential health problems associated with the painkillers.

text: Good thing CA is able to focus on this hugely important issue and doesn't have massive homelessness plaguing it's cities or an ever increasing affordable housing crisis to worry about.

text: I'm so glad CA is at the forefront of tackling our nation's most pressing issues. Keep being a beacon of hope CA and I'm sure other states will follow.

text: The policies of the last eight years and -- and Washington's unwillingness to tackle the tough problems for decades has left us in the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to tradition.

the premise relies on the assumption that the current economic crisis is the worst since the great depression based on tradition rather than concrete evidence.

text: And that's why the biggest risk we could take right now is to adopt the same failed policies and the same failed politics that we've seen over the last eight years and somehow expect a different result.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to repetition.

the argument suggests that the current political and policy decisions have failed in the past eight years, and thus will fail again if repeated.

text: Ive collectively had sex hundreds of times with my partners over the years, that doesn't make me better than someone who's had sex with more people, one time each.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to equivalence.

the sentence suggests that having sex with many partners is not better than having sex with fewer partners. this is an appeal to equivalence because it suggests that the quantity of sexual experiences is the only factor that determines worth or value.

text: Almost everyone in the world will look more favorably on a person who has had sex 100x times with one person versus having sex 1x each with 100 different people.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to positive emotion.

the argument suggests that people will have a more positive view of someone who has had multiple sexual encounters with one partner compared to someone who has had a single sexual encounter with many different partners, purely based on the number of sexual encounters, without considering other factors or qualities that might influence the way people view others.

text: I work 6 ten hour days very frequently and don't get weekends off. In a way it's pretty insulting to see people angry with a 9-5 40 hour work week. I'd be so grateful to have that extra time to spend with my family and friends.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to worse problems.

the author suggests that people with traditional 9-5 jobs are lucky because they have more time for family and friends than the author who works long hours.

text: A few students are misbehaving...therefore the whole class is bad.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to hasty generalization.

the premise states that a few students are misbehaving, but the conclusion drawn is that the whole class is bad. this is an appeal to hasty generalization, as it is not valid to assume that all members of a group are equally responsible for the actions of a few.

text: It implies an existing framework of what the extremes of diet are or can be.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to tradition.

the premise assumes that there exists a traditional framework of what the extremes of diet are or can be, which is then used as evidence to support the conclusion.

text: For example, if we're speaking'natural' diet. Balance can't include any refined sugar at all because we weren't able to process it. Before the food pyramid came around the upper end of sugar consumption would have been much lower.

text: But irrespective of whether he thinks it is or not means less than fact that this country cannot morally and socially and economically accept an economy running out the clock on the 20th Century.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to tradition.

text: We're treading water. We have families that are hurting. We have people who are unemployed. We have people with no property. We have an administration that is demolishing public housing in our inner cities and not providing anything else but more public housing.

text: Their solution to the inner city is more -- excuse the expression but it's true,"socialism."

text: Over 5 million Filipinos use our products. It's time to switch to our brand now!

answer: appeal to authority.

text: it's clear enough so that there are 2.18 billion Christians

text: And the budget plan that I've put out, according to the"Los Angeles Times" again, the way these things are typically measured as a percentage of the GDP, will bring government spending down to the lowest level in 50 years. So I want to proceed carefully to cover more people.

answer: appeal to tradition.

text: Our military is the strongest military in the world. It is the strongest, best prepared, best equipped it has ever been.

answer: appeal to authority.

answer: circular reasoning.

the argument commits circular reasoning because it uses the premise "murder is morally wrong" to support the conclusion "abortion is morally wrong", and then uses the conclusion to reinforce the premise.

text: I bought a ticket to win a new car at the mall, since I have never won anything like that in the past.

text: Our ancestors used to depend on it to survive, so I can see how it might be in someone's genome to want to hunt. Hunting is almost entirely aligned with the natural cycle of life, factory farming in horrible conditions isn't.

answer: appeal to tradition.

text: He was right, but then he put in place deficits twice that size for every one of his four years.

answer: appeal to sentiment.

the sentence suggests that metallica's creativity, rather than their technical skills, is what made them the greatest metal band of all time. this is an appeal to sentiment, as it relies on emotions rather than objective evidence to support the claim.

text: Every one I remember seeing has proven itself to be between 50% and 90% overstated. Our death counts ended up being 10% of what the models were forecasting.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to authority.

the text relies on the alleged authority of personal experience to undermine the accuracy of models.

text: They claim they don't have the personnel to staff them....despite the state's NG being given authorization from our governor to send its stock of nurses and doctors to do it.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to authority.

the sentence suggests that the state's national guard (ng) has been authorized by the governor to send nurses and doctors to staff the healthcare facilities, implying that the healthcare facilities do have the necessary personnel.

text: It makes me wonder of it was just the usual bureaucratic waste or if they've got a future use in mind for the facility...
actual_label:
answer: appeal to speculation.

the sentence suggests that the author is speculating about the future use of the facility, rather than presenting any factual evidence or reliable information.

text: You havent played but are talking about it like this? Oof
actual_label:
answer: appeal to anger.

the sentence suggests that the person is expressing anger or frustration towards the speaker because they have not played the game but are still offering an opinion about it.

text: Imagine being a horny naive 16 year old. You were talking to a girl, you guys exchange nudes. You're 21. It's been revealed to other adults that you sent a picture of your dick (nice cock btw). You're on the sex offender registry. You will get almost all job offers turned down. Your life is fucked because someone decided your life should be shit for being a horny teenager.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to pity.

the author is attempting to elicit sympathy for the individual by describing the potential consequences of their actions, rather than presenting objective evidence or logical reasoning.

text: 21 year old aren't teenagers
actual_label: answer: appeal to false authority. the premise lacks evidence to support the conclusion that 21 year olds are not teenagers.

text: If this was just people getting details mixed up, the Mandela Effect would not sustain the interest it has.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to tradition.

the mandela effect is a widely discussed phenomenon that suggests that a significant portion of the population falsely remembers certain historical events differently than they actually occurred. this suggests that the mandela effect is not simply a matter of people getting details mixed up.

text: a lot of leftists are mad that its 1400 checks not 2000, because it was meant to supplement the 600 passed in december
actual_label:
answer: appeal to frustration.

the author implies that the reduction in the number of stimulus checks from $2,000 to $1,400 is the sole reason for the dissatisfaction of leftists.

text: If Kavanaugh is innocent he should be yelling from the hills demanding an investigation by the FBI.
actual_label: answer: appeal to emotion. the argument suggests that if kavanaugh is innocent, he should behave in a certain way (yelling for an investigation), based on an emotional response rather than logical reasoning.

text: If Dr. Ford *is* lying, then Republicans should be *eager* to get her in front of an FBI interrogator.
actual_label: answer: appeal to emotion (specifically, eagerness motivated by the premise that the doctor is lying).

text: The government has no right to spilt up your business
actual_label:
answer: appeal to tradition.

the traditional view of government is that it should not interfere in the private lives or businesses of citizens.

text: But every time I bring this point up, GOP_Fanboy just reverts to "lol who are you to decide who gets paid what communist etc"
actual_label: answer: appeal to authority. gop_fanboy's response suggests that the speaker is not an authority on determining salaries for government officials.
